awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Comparative analyses of structural designs underlying functional performance of the toughest spider silk
awd_abstract_narration:
Spider silks are the toughest materials in nature and hold immense promise to inspire a new generation of high-performance synthetic biomaterials. In the rainforests of Madagascar, Darwin's bark spider spins giant orb webs across rivers and lakes using a silk that is far tougher than silk produced by any other known spider. This project aims to understand how Darwin's bark spider produces such 'super' silk and how the silk functions in these giant webs. Through comparison to closely related species, the project will test how newly discovered spinning gland modifications and silk proteins found in Darwin's bark spider interact to produce super tough silk, and if those features are necessary to spin giant webs across rivers. Insight gained from these exceptional spiders will aid in the development of super-silk proteins that can inspire the design of new high-performance materials. Students and postdoctoral researchers will be trained to conduct interdisciplinary research, through direct participation in the project in the US and Madagascar, and through the development of curriculum for a variety of courses, including those offered by The University of Akron's Biomimicry Research and Innovation Center. Public outreach showcasing the natural history of these engaging spiders will provide a platform for linking the study of biodiversity to technological innovation.  Such broader impacts will be achieved through an exhibit at the University of Vermont's Natural History Museum and educational activities for students in grades 5-9 at the Tsongas Industrial History Center at Lowell National Historical Park.


This project will investigate silk production, structure and biomechanics among Darwin's bark spider (Caerostris darwini) and its close relatives in a comparative framework to determine the key design features underlying super-tough silk and how they evolved with web ecology. The objectives are to: 1) quantify the material properties of dragline fibers and kinematics of Caerostris webs; 2) characterize the structural proteins and spinning gland morphology that form Caerostris dragline silk; and 3) develop a robust Caerostris species phylogeny to infer the evolutionary causes and consequences of extremely tough silk. The work integrates genomic and proteomic analyses of silk proteins with functional characterization of silk threads and finite element modelling of web function and spider ecology. An evolutionary framework provided by phylogenomic analyses will test which traits facilitated the origin of super-tough silk and its implications for the evolution of giant spider webs.

por.por_cntn:
Spider silks include some of the toughest known biomaterials and have been intensely studied for decades to understand the basis for their outstanding mechanical properties.  Silk production is particularly impressive in orb-web weaving spiders that produce seven distinct silk types for different functional purposes. Among these seven silk types, dragline (also known as major ampullate silk) is used by orb-weavers to construct the radii and framelines of their web, and orb-weaver dragline is by far the best studied silk type due to its high tensile strength and ease of collection. This award supported research aimed at characterizing the molecular basis for the extreme toughness of the toughest measured dragline silk - dragline from Darwin's bark spider (Caerostris darwini). This species constructs some of the largest webs measured across streams and rivers in the rainforests of Madagascar, and the extreme toughness of its dragline may be critical to support its giant webs. 

 Researchers in this project used advanced genomic technologies to sequence gene transcripts expressed in the specialized glands that produce major ampullate silk as well as from glands producing the silk that forms the web's extensible capture spiral from 12 species in the bark spider genus Caerostris, including Darwin's bark spider. This allowed the team to determine dragline protein sequences and predict their relative abundance in dragline.  The team collaborated with experts in spider silk biomechanics to also measure the material properties of these species' dragline, and also collected molecular structural data directly from dragline of these same bark spider species.  The work shows that variation in the abundance of specific proteins in dragline may be important to explaining variation in fiber toughness and provides a roadmap for producing extremely tough artificial spider silk using genetic engineering.  The work also produced extensive databases of gene transcripts and their proteins from bark spider species which, in addition to standard DNA barcoding techniques, has revealed the evolutionary relationships of these species, and provides a basis for understanding how silk genes are evolving. 

In addition to the listed publications, the work resulted in seven presentations at national scientific conferences and six invited seminars or other public presentations.  The work also resulted in the training of several University of Massachusetts Lowell students in laboratory techniques and bioinformatic analyses, including three graduate students and eight undergraduate students, resulting in one Master's thesis and two undergraduate Honors theses. Additional broader impact activities supported by this award include after school programming at three different public elementary schools in Lowell, Massachusetts in association with the Tsongas Industrial History Center (TIHC), as well as in two TIHC summer camps.  This involved presentations and hands-on demonstrations with live and preserved spiders, including introduction to the use of microscopes, for an estimated 86 students in grades 3-9.  The award also supported an additional public outreach event and an educational video produced with the Lowell National Historic Park.
